metadata.title: Spinal Tumor
anatomical location body part affected: Vertebral bodies, lamina, intraforaminal spaces, spinal cord (extradural, intradural, or intramedullary), or nerve roots of any spinal level
description: A spinal tumor is a growth that develops within or near the spinal cord or within the bones of the spine. A spinal tumor can affect the nerves in the area surrounding it, which can lead to pain, neurological impairments, and disability

Spinal tumors can be classified as extradural, intradural intramedullary, and intradural extramedullary (16) –55-60%  of spinal tumors are extradural tumors and are usually metastatic from other sites. They are considered secondary spinal tumors -60–70%  of extradural tumors occur in the thoracic spine, 20–30%  in the lumbar spine, and 10% in the cervical spine(17) -Thirty percent of patients with metastases will have tumors in more than one area of the spine(17) –20–30%  of spinal tumors are intradural intramedullary -Gliomas make up 80% of intramedullary tumors. Gliomas are further subdivided into astrocytomas and ependymomas –Of the remaining spinal tumors, most are intradural extramedullary -This type is found most often in the thoracic region –Living environment:  Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

ICD-10 codes.C41.2: malignant neoplasm of vertebral column, excluding sacrum and coccyx
ICD-10 codes.C79.4: secondary malignant neoplasm of other and unspecified parts of nervous system
ICD-10 codes.C79.5: secondary malignant neoplasm of bone and bone marrow
ICD-10 codes.D16.6: benign neoplasm of vertebral column, excluding sacrum and coccyx
ICD-10 codes.D48.0: neoplasm of uncertain or unknown behavior of bone and articular cartilage
ICD-10 codes.ICD: codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Pain is the most common presenting symptom of spinal tumors(6) –Insidious, intractable spinal pain –Pain can be local, radicular, or referred –Pain is typically worse at night and with rest –Pain is often worse in the supine position –Thoracic spinal cord tumors can cause chronic abdominal pain –Intradural tumors are associated with radicular pain and nocturnal pain(3)
Unexplained weight loss –Tumor growth leads to excess metabolism of nutrients, leading to unexplained weight loss and pathologic fracture of vertebrae
Progressive musculoskeletal deformities –Tumors in the cervical and thoracic spine may cause paraplegia if there is a collapse of a vertebral body with subsequent compression of the cord

Approximately 1 in 20 patients with malignant spinal tumors can develop spinal cord compression, also known as metastatic spinal cord compression (MSCC).(6) Tumors that involve the nerve roots or spinal column lead to motor, sensory, and functional impairments. Distribution of neurological deficits is based on the location of the lesion(6) –Motor dysfunctions include weakness, fatigue, spasticity, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and extensor plantar response (Babinski reflex) –Sensory dysfunctions include numbness and paresthesias
Loss of bowel and bladder function or difficulty walking may be noted Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Primary malignancies that most commonly metastasize to the spine are lymphoma, multiple myeloma, and lung, breast,prostate, kidney, and colon tumors(6)–Ten percent of all patients with cancer will develop symptomatic spinal metastases; of these, 50% will develop pain andneurologic deficits(4)

Primary malignant neoplasms of the spine are rare, accounting for < 5% of spinal tumors; they include:(4)–multiple myeloma, plasmacytoma, osteoblastoma–chordoma (mid-vertebral  body; destructive and rare)

Benign neoplasms are also rare–Types of benign neoplasms include osteoid osteoma, eosinophilic granuloma, aneurysmal bone cyst, giant cell tumor,ependymoma, neurofibroma, schwannoma, lipoma, and meningioma-Neurofibromas and schwannomas arise from Schwann cells of the nerve roots(6)-Multiple neurofibromas indicate the increased likelihood of neurofibromatosis(6)-Ependymomas arise from cells lining the central canal; nearly all are benign(6)
Intradural spinal tumors are rare—annual incidence is 2–4/1,000,000(3)
pathogenesis: Abnormal cell growth in the spinal cord or vertebral column occurs from either primary or secondary sources(16)–A spinal tumor is primary when the spine is the original site of abnormal growth–Secondary spinal tumors are metastatic growths of abnormal cells from another area in the body spreading to the vertebralcolumn
Spinal cord tumors result in compression and traction of the spinal cord, spinal nerve roots, and vertebral arteries, and havean effect on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) circulation
risk factors: The greatest risk factor is the presence of existing malignant cells in the body that can metastasize to the spine–The most common sources are the breast, myeloma, colon, lung, lymphoma, prostate, and kidney(6,17)

Other risk factors–Family history of cancer–Exposure to carcinogenic material–Smoking–Meningiomas occur more often in females(6)–Age: certain tumors are more likely to occur in childhood or adulthood-Ependymomas are more common in adults(6)-Astrocytomas are more common in children(6)

overall contraindications precautions: Medical intervention is required for this condition. If this condition is suspected (and patient does not yet have a formal diagnosis or is being seen through direct access), the patient should immediately be referred to a physician for further testing
Follow physician’s orders and/or protocol; obtain clear instructions regarding acceptable activities

Monitor patient for signs and symptoms of serious complications of medical treatment (e.g., DVT) and contact physician immediately should they develop Please see Clinical Review…Deep Vein Thrombosis: Exercise ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708457 for more information on signs and symptoms and prevention
Activity should begin only after patient is medically stable, spinal stability has been restored, and patient has been medically cleared(1)
Follow the facility’s guidelines regarding evaluation and treatment guidelines for the pediatric population

Any treatment that increases the proliferation rate of tumor cells must be avoided with this patient population. These include the use of therapeutic or electromagnetic modalities or use of massage techniques prior to medical management of the cancer

MSCC is considered an emergency and can result in paralysis and associated loss of independence. Symptoms include pain in back or neck (including radiating pain), numbness in toes and fingers, difficulty walking, very little urine output, bowel and bladder incontinence, and constipation(17)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Etiology of illness -Is this tumor primary or secondary? If secondary, where is the primary tumor? -When was the tumor diagnosed? -Intradural tumors grow slowly(6) -Intramedullary tumors are more insidious and progress slowly over weeks or months(6)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Who makes up the medical team? Radiation oncologist, medical oncologist, spine surgeon, pain management specialist, radiologist, psychiatrist, nursing, and case worker are key members of the patient’s medical team What medical intervention has occurred (e.g., surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy)? Any complications following medical intervention? Radiation therapy is directed at the tumor and started as early as possible in cases of metastatic disease External beam radiation therapy (EBRT) can cause significant pain or increase the patient’s risk for developing a pathological fracture or spinal cord compression. It is used primarily as palliative care(5) Stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) is considered for spinal metastases as primary treatment, postoperative treatment, or salvage treatment after EBRT or spinal cord decompression(5) Surgical treatment options vary depending on whether the tumor is a primary or secondary lesion(4) Spinal tumors are surgically removed through decompression of neurological elements and stabilization of the spinal column to preserve neurological function(4) Surgical decompression with laminectomy is rarely performed or needed as radiation is effective in most cases of compressive metastatic tumors. Minimally invasive surgery is a treatment option for patients with neurological deficits, pain, and spinal instability(6) Surgical removal of primary tumors Surgery is the treatment of choice for most extramedullary tumors, which usually are benign(6) Intramedullary tumors are surgically removed(6) Ependymomas are often clearly demarcated and able to be completely removed(6)  Astrocytomas can be surgically removed; however, if there is evidence of malignancy or removal is incomplete, postoperative radiation typically is required(6)
course of treatment.medications: Current American College of Radiology guidelines recommend the following interventions for spinal bone metastases(5) Systemic chemotherapy and/or hormonal therapy and osteoclast inhibitors are administered when asymptomatic bone metastases are first diagnosed(5) Radiopharmaceuticals are generally considered in patients with persistent multifocal sites of pain or recurrence of pain in a previously irradiated site(5) Corticosteroids are prescribed to ameliorate neurological symptoms, reduce edema, and reduce pain(6) If not contraindicated, steroids are recommended for any patient with neurological deficits who is suspected of having or is confirmed to have metastatic extradural spinal cord compression, but there is no consensus on the dosage Steroids generally are continued until radiation therapy is complete and then gradually tapered Patients with compression but no neurologic deficits generally do not require steroids Opioid analgesics can be prescribed for pain management
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Testing may include:
Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP), CBC, ESR, calcium, phosphate, AP, acid phosphatase, PSA, CEA, TSH, CT(6)
MRI  optimal choice for spinal tumors(6)
Can provide excellent visualization of tumor and involved structures(6)
Able to differentiate tumors from other masses such as abscesses and hematomas(6)
Gadolinium-enhanced  and non-contrast-enhanced MRI sequences are standard(6)
Chemical shift MRI can be a useful tool in differentiating benign lesions from malignant spinal lesions and has a sensitivity of 91.7% and specificity of 73.3%(15)
X-rays  are unable to identify a substantial percentage of the tumors(6)
Tissue biopsy to identify the primary source of tumor if spinal metastasis is suspected(6)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Pain typically is relieved with activity and more noticeable with rest and at night(6) -Pain usually is worse in the supine position(6) -Pain that worsens with coughing and sneezing suggests vertebral metastasis(6)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and/or nature of symptoms -Meningiomas are often located posterior to the spinal cord in the thoracic region or near the foramen magnum(6) -Ependymomas are most commonly located in the cervical cord or near the cauda equina and filum terminale(6) -Astrocytomas are most often located in the cervical cord(6)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Symptoms include intractable spinal pain (radicular or local), numbness, and paresthesias. Pain can be referred -Pain typically is unremitting(6) -Local tenderness typically is present on palpation(6)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, on average, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). The Oucher Scale can be used for pediatric patients
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night -Pain usually is worse at night and interferes with sleep
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, fatigue, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, progression of neurological symptoms) -Recommend patient complete a quality of life assessment tool such as the SF-36  or SF-12
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any respiratory compromise? If so, does the patient require ventilator assistance? Does the patient require oxygen supplementation? If so, how much? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document history of cancer, spinal injuries, or other musculoskeletal or neurological conditions
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other medical conditions, including diabetes, heart disease, asthma/ respiratory compromise, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders In a study conducted in Switzerland, back/neck pain as a leading symptom and coexisting degenerative spine disease in adjacent spinal segments was present in 27/58 (47%) of the patients with intradural spinal tumor(3)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient work or attend school? What type of work? Is the patient not able to do any of his or her favorite activities because of pain?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any noted limitations and equipment in

other: Medical intervention is required for this condition. If this condition is suspected (and the patient does not yet have a formal diagnosis), the patient should immediately be referred to a physician for further testing. Activity should begin only after the patient is medically stable and spinal stability has been restored(1)

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies.  Follow physician’s orders and/or protocol regarding rehabilitation
Patients with unstable spinal lesions are, in most cases, immobilized due to the risk of pathological fracture and the associated risk of spinal cord compression(10)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Physical therapy is recommended for patients who present with pain, fatigue, decreased functional mobility, decreased independence with ADLs, reduced cardiorespiratory endurance, and decreased strength and ROM. Physical therapy is also indicated for patients in order to reduce the effects of fatigue and disability associated with medical treatments such as chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgical interventions. Physical therapy may also be prescribed for palliative intervention
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Multiple sclerosis Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) Herniated disk Syringomyelia Cauda equina syndrome Spinal stenosis Ankylosing spondylitis Rheumatoid arthritis Osteoarthritis Pott disease(13) Osteoporosis Pathological fracture Herniation of nucleus pulposus (pain worse with activity)
prognosis: In an investigation into the preoperative factors associated with primary spinal tumor mortality, researchers from Hungary concluded that patient age, spinal region, tumor grade, spinal pain, motor deficit, and myelopathy/cauda equine syndrome were significantly associated with poor survival(11) –From this, the authors developed the Primary Spinal Tumor Mortality Score (PSTMS), where lower scores (0-2)were significantly associated with low mortalityand higher scores (5+) associated with high mortality in this study of 323 consecutive patients with primary spinal tumors treated surgically over an 18-year  period
The most important prognostic factor is the histology of the spinal tumor(7)
Early diagnosis may lead to better outcomes(7)
The 5-year  survival rate for patients with benign or low-grade  spinal cord neoplasms is greater than 90%(7)
In a series study of patients with ependymomas, the tumor recurrence rate was 7%; however, patients with astrocytoma, a more aggressive and less common tumor type, had a recurrence rate of 48%(7)

The Oswestry Spinal Risk Index is a tool that predicts survival in patients with MSCC. Lower scores on the OSRI predict longer survival rates in patients with MSCC(14) –Authors of a systematic review on quality of life of patients with MSCC found that a significant percentage of patients are distressed, butalso found low levels of distress and good quality of life in general in over 50% of patients(18)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Referral back to oncologist if advancement of symptoms is noted Referral to an occupational therapist (OT) for formal ADL and self-care  evaluation and adaptive equipment Referral to social worker to assist with community resources Referral to clinical psychologist  Referral to an orthotist for bracing and a nurse for bowel and bladder training may be warranted
other considerations: Surgical decompression may be more effective than radiotherapy in the treatment of patients with MSCC presenting with myelopathy; however, complications need to be considered(19) –Based on a retrospective study conducted in Japan of 56 patients, 20 who had received radiotherapy and 36 who had received decompression and stabilization surgery with and without radiotherapy –Seven patients in the radiotherapy-only  group required surgery eventually. Of the remaining 13 patients, one patient showed improvement in neurological symptoms.Thirty-four  patients in the surgery group showed improvement –One patient in the radiotherapy group and 21 patients in the surgery group were ambulatory after treatment –Surgery-related  complications occurred in nine patients and six required re-operation.  No major complications were seen in the radiotherapy group
treatment summary: A consensus opinion from experts and a literature search indicated that patients with malignant or benign spinal tumor causing spinal cord dysfunction should be admitted to specialist spinal rehabilitation units (SRUs)(20) –Respondents indicated that 83% of patients with benign tumors are admitted to SRUs, but only 45% of patients with malignant tumors
Physical therapy interventions will vary significantly based on the level of neurologic dysfunction, stage of disease, and life expectancy
Physical therapy is indicated for patients who present with decreased functional mobility, impaired ADLs, pain, loss of strength, decreased ROM, and deconditioning

Results of a randomized controlled trial in Germany that examined the effects of exercises for strengthening paravertebral muscles in patients with spinal bone metastases indicate that isometric resistance training is safe and feasible,(8) can improve pain relief, and can improve functional capacity, reduce fatigue, and enhance quality of life(10) –While undergoing radiotherapy, 60 patients were randomized into a group receiving isometric resistance training or a group receiving passive physical therapy –There were no measurable side effects in the exercise group(8) –Patients in the exercise group improved in pain score over the course of the intervention and pain scores were significantly better after 3 months –Measures targeting quality of life, fatigue, and emotional distress were significantly improved after 3 months and 6 months in the resistance exercise group(10) –The survival of patients with spinal bone metastases is poor. Six patients died within 6 months of radiotherapy due to tumor progression. The effects of resistance training became apparent and significant after 6 months, which indicates a higher benefit for survivors(9) –Further study is warranted

There is insufficient evidence regarding patient positioning and bracing for pain relief and spinal stability for patients with MSCC(2) –Based on a 2012 systematic Cochrane review that evaluated the effects of positioning and bracing in individuals with metastatic cord compression and spinal instability who were not candidates for surgical intervention –Of 1,611 potentially relevant studies, there were no studies that met the inclusion criteria. Many studies identified the importance of patient positioning/mobilization, but there were no RCTs studying the effects of bracing for this patient population –Researchers concluded there is no evidence to guide clinicians in the use and efficacy of bracing for reducing pain or improving quality of life. In addition, there is a lack of evidence to guide clinicians on how to correctly position and when to mobilize these patients –Authors of a 2015 update to this Cochrane review came to the same conclusion, stating that no new studies were found and their conclusions remain unchanged(12) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Patient has decreased knowledge regarding orthotics and ability to manage orthoticsPatient/caregiver will be independent in management of orthoticsPatient/caregiver

maintenance or prevention: Patients should follow the recommendations and any home exercise program provided by the therapist and clinical care team
Patients should be monitored closely by a multidisciplinary team of healthcare professionals for local tumor recurrence and symptom management
patient education: Information on spinal cord tumors can be found at Macmillan Cancer Support, http://www.macmillan.org.uk/information-and-support/spinal-cord-tumours
The National Cancer Institute’s website on the treatment of brain and spinal cord tumors in children is found at https://www.cancer.gov/types/brain/patient/child-brain-treatment-pdq

American Cancer Society’s information on brain and spinal cord tumors in adults is available at https://www.cancer.org/cancer/brain-spinal-cord-tumors-adults.html Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
